front.question: When relaying patient information via radio, communications should be:
Which type of communications equipment functions as a radio receiver and searches across several frequencies?
Two-way communication that requires the EMT to “push to talk” and “release to listen” describes which mode of communication?

choices: Unlike adults, children cannot see through lies or deceptions.
Most children are intrigued by strangers wearing uniforms.
The EMT should give the child minimal information to avoid scaring him or her.
Standing over a child often increases his or her level of anxiety.
front.question: Which of the following statements regarding communication with a child is correct?

cards.back: Standing over a child often increases his or her level of anxiety.

choices: recall that most visually impaired patients are blind.
possess an in-depth knowledge of sign language.
expect the patient to have difficulty understanding.
determine the degree of the patient’s impairment.
front.question: When communicating with a visually impaired patient, you should:

cards.back: determine the degree of the patient’s impairment.

front.question: A patient’s refusal of EMS treatment and/or transport must be:

choices: place the patient in a high-visibility area and then respond to the call.
inform the admissions clerk of the situation and then respond at once.
respond only after giving a verbal patient report to a nurse or physician.
leave a copy of the run form with a nurse and then respond to the call.
front.question: As you are wheeling your patient through the emergency department doors, you receive another call for a major motor vehicle crash. You should:

cards.back: respond only after giving a verbal patient report to a nurse or physician.

front.question: Any radio hardware containing a transmitter and a receiver that is located in a fixed location is called a:

choices: considering your own cultural values as more important when interacting with people of a different culture.
subconsciously forcing your cultural values onto a patient because you believe that your own values are more acceptable.
suspecting that a person has an ulterior motive based on the tone of his or her voice when answering a question.
understanding that people from different cultural backgrounds respond to pain and stress differently.
front.question: Ethnocentrism is defined as:

cards.back: considering your own cultural values as more important when interacting with people of a different culture.

front.question: A ___________ receives messages and signals on one frequency and then automatically retransmits them on a second frequency.

choices: discouraging the caller from providing care until the EMS unit arrives.
coordinating responding EMS units with other public safety personnel.
selecting and notifying the correct EMS response units and personnel.
screening and assigning a priority to each call based on local protocols.
front.question: During the alert and dispatch phase of EMS communications, the dispatcher’s responsibilities include all of the following, except:

cards.back: discouraging the caller from providing care until the EMS unit arrives.

choices: not disclosing his or her name.
front.question: When providing a patient report via radio, you should protect the patient’s privacy by:

cards.back: not disclosing his or her name.

front.question: The patient care report (PCR) ensures:

choices: placing yourself in a position to ensure that the patient can see your lips.
shining a light on your face when you are in a darkened environment.
providing pen and paper if the patient prefers to write his or her response.
elevating the tone of your voice and exaggerating word pronunciation.
front.question: Communicating with hearing-impaired patients can be facilitated by doing all of the following, except:

cards.back: elevating the tone of your voice and exaggerating word pronunciation.

front.question: In which of the following manners should you act and speak with a patient?
You could be sued for ___________ if your radio report to the hospital describes the patient in a manner that injures his or her reputation.

choices: “I notice that you are a retired paramedic, so I’m sure you will understand all of the things that we will be doing to you.”
“This is nothing to worry about. Please try to stay calm. The physician at the hospital will probably not find any signs of a heart problem.”
“We need to take you to the ED stat. We will give you ASA and NTG en route and then reassess your vitals. Do you have any questions?”
“It is possible that you are experiencing a heart attack. I am going to give you four baby aspirin to chew and swallow.”
front.question: You are caring for a 52-year-old man who complains of chest discomfort. The patient is a retired paramedic and is very anxious because he thinks he is having a heart attack. Which of the following statements would be appropriate?

cards.back: “It is possible that you are experiencing a heart attack. I am going to give you four baby aspirin to chew and swallow.”

choices: withholding unpleasant information until arrival at the hospital.
maintaining eye contact with the patient whenever possible.
using medical terminology to ensure the patient understands.
positioning yourself at a level that is higher than the patient.
front.question: Calming and reassuring an anxious patient can be facilitated by:

cards.back: maintaining eye contact with the patient whenever possible.

front.question: All information recorded on the PCR must be:
Which of the following incidents does not require a report to be filed with local authorities?
